title: Reading Comprehension: Analyzing Nonfiction Texts

vocab.definition: The most important point or central message of a text
Facts, examples, or explanations that support the main idea
A conclusion reached using evidence and reasoning
The reason why an author wrote a text: to inform, persuade, or entertain
How information is organized in a text, such as cause-and-effect or compare-contrast

teachingNotes: Use current events and science articles. Practice identifying different text structures. Teach students to distinguish between facts and opinions in nonfiction.

sample.question: What is the most important point of a text called?

truefalse.question: An inference is a conclusion you reach using evidence and reasoning.

multiplechoice.question: If an author writes to convince you of something, what is their purpose?

fillintheblank.question: Facts and examples that support the main idea are called ________ details.

shortanswer.question: What are three common ways authors organize nonfiction texts?
